title: How to Care for Dark Clothing and Retain Color

steps.headline: Separate dark and light clothing.
steps.description: Dark clothing requires extra gentle washing and can also bleed onto lighter clothes if they're washed at the same time. Therefore, always separate dark and light clothing before doing laundry. Darker garments should be washed separately.

steps.headline: Turn dark clothing inside out.
steps.description: The less exposure dark fabrics get to water and detergent, the better. Turning your clothing inside out before washing it minimizes contact with water and soap.

steps.headline: Pick a detergent for dark clothing.
steps.description: For best results, look for a detergent specifically formulated to wash dark clothes. A basic detergent that's free of additives is your best option. Avoid things like "color-safe bleach," as no bleach is actually 100% color safe. While you should avoid most additives, a built-in fabric softener is a good idea, especially one specifically formulated for dark clothes.

steps.headline: Opt for a shorter cycle.
steps.description: Pick the shortest cycle offered by your washer or dryer. A briefer cycle minimizes dark clothing's exposure to water and soap, reducing the amount of damage it accrues.

steps.headline: Use cold water.
steps.description: Choose the coldest water setting possible. Cold water does not cause as much fading and bleeding in the wash. Never wash dark clothes in warm or hot water.

steps.headline: Add a cup of vinegar during the rinse cycle.
steps.description: White vinegar can help prevent the build up of residue from detergent. Detergent residue is a major culprit in dark clothing becoming faded. During the rinse cycle, open your washer and add a cup of white vinegar.

steps.headline: Hang dry your clothes.
steps.description: The less time dark clothing spends in the dryer, the better. It's best to hang your dark clothes to dry. Do not hang your clothes in direct sunlight, however, as sun exposure can fade color.

methods.name: Minimizing the Need to Wash Dark Clothes

steps.headline: Make sure you're clean before wearing your clothes.
steps.description: The less often you have to wash dark clothing, the better. Before throwing on dark clothes, make sure you're clean yourself. Putting on dark clothes when you're sweaty or messy will get your clothes dirty faster, meaning you'll need to wash them more often.

steps.headline: Carry sprays to treat stains promptly.
steps.description: Invest in a small tube of stain remover, which you can buy at any drugstore or department store. If you get something on your clothing while wearing it out, promptly apply the stain remover according to package directions. Spot treating stains and spills in the moment will result in you needing to clean clothing less often.

steps.headline: Avoid doing chores in dark clothing.
steps.description: Cleaning or doing yard work is bad for dark clothing. If you do work that requires kneeling, it'll fade out the knee area. Yard work, scrubbing the floors, and similar tasks should be avoided when wearing dark clothes.

steps.headline: Rotate your clothes.
steps.description: You can wear dark clothing more than once before washing it. However, rotating your clothes will keep them fresher longer. Never wear the same dark garment more than one day in a row. Rotating clothing will prevent damage and cut down on the need for washing.

steps.headline: Store your clothing properly.
steps.description: Dark clothing should be stored in a dark, cool place in your home. Avoid areas prone to humidity, like bathrooms or basements. If you use hangers, opt for hangers with plush arms. These are less likely to stretch out your clothes.

steps.headline: Wash dark clothing less.
steps.description: Only wear dark clothing for short periods to prevent the need to wash it. For example, wear a black dress or suit out for an evening and take it off immediately when you get home. Wear black pants only indoors. You can get away with wearing an item of dark clothing three or four times before washing it.

steps.headline: Avoid doing your hair and makeup while wearing dark clothes.
steps.description: Chemicals from things like makeup, hairspray, and hair gel can damage dark clothes. If you're wearing something dark for a night out, do your hair and makeup before getting dressed.
